items.title: RFC 7395: Extensible Messaging and Presence Protocol (XMPP) Subprotocol for WebSocket

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: Duplicate of another issue inside this project. Close this one.

items.body:
Are there any plans on implementing support for this transport layer?
There's already some libraries that use this protocol such as [this one](https://github.com/Terbau/fortnitepy/blob/master/fortnitepy/xmpp.py)

items.body:

```py
C:\Users\AppData\Local\Packages\PythonSoftwareFoundation.Python.3.8_qbz5n2kfra8p0\LocalCache\local-packages\Python38\site-packages\aioxmpp\callbacks.py:605
```

items.title: How To Connect Server With Anonymous SASL ? (XEP-0034: SASL Integration) Always startttls
items.body:
Hi there, I was trying to connect my prosody server with Anonymous SASL .

I looked up for the document for a while, nothing helped me at all. 

Let's go straight for the problem:

my code for creating security layer is as below (I refered from issues#153):
```python
aioxmpp.make_security_layer(None,pin_store=None,anonymous=True,no_verify=True,)._replace(tls_required=False)
```

When I trying to connect to my xmpp server , it always failed on ssl handshake (yes, I'm not enable ssl on my server), xmpp server sample log:

```log

c2s559bbc37cd90                                       debug     Client sent opening <stream:stream> to daily.signaling.teamlink.co
c2s559bbc37cd90                                       debug     Sending[c2s_unauthed]: <?xml version='1.0'?>
```

while we use strophe.js with Anonymous SASL, our xmpp print log as below (desired) :
```log
c2s559bbc22b010                                       info      Client connected
c2s559bbc22b010                                       debug     Sending WebSocket handshake
mod_websocket                                         debug     Websocket received frame: opcode=1, 98 bytes
c2s559bbc22b010                                       debug     Client sent opening <stream:stream> to daily.signaling.teamlink.co
c2s559bbc22b010                                       debug     Sending[c2s_unauthed]: <open xml:lang='en' id='b995f089-1f6c-4053-8883-d5e7058ebe34' version='1.0' xmlns='urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:xmpp-framing' from='daily.signaling.teamlink.co'>
c2s559bbc22b010                                       debug     Sent reply <stream:stream> to client
c2s559bbc22b010                                       debug     Offering mechanism ANONYMOUS
c2s559bbc22b010                                       debug     Sending[c2s_unauthed]: <stream:features>
mod_websocket                                         debug     Websocket received frame: opcode=1, 70 bytes
runnerKraT7FRy                                        debug     creating new coroutine
c2s559bbc22b010                                       debug     Received[c2s_unauthed]: <auth mechanism='ANONYMOUS' xmlns='urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:xmpp-sasl'>

c2s559bbc22b010                                       debug     Client sent opening <stream:stream> to daily.signaling.teamlink.co
c2s559bbc22b010                                       debug     Sending[c2s_unbound]: <open xml:lang='en' id='bb797d51-b533-4853-8db0-717a52977bec' version='1.0' xmlns='urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:xmpp-framing' from='daily.signaling.teamlink.co'>

```

as I can infer from the log difference, the key problem is , aioxmpp's TLS is not disabled, orI'm not using correct SASL provider.

when I using aioxmpp:
```
runner0jAgbaK0                                        debug     creating new coroutine
c2s559bbc37cd90                                       debug     Received[c2s_unauthed]: <starttls xmlns='urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:xmpp-tls'>
c2s559bbc37cd90                                       debug     Sending[c2s_unauthed]: <proceed xmlns='urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:xmpp-tls'>
```

the correct one:
```
runnerKraT7FRy                                        debug     creating new coroutine
c2s559bbc22b010                                       debug     Received[c2s_unauthed]: <auth mechanism='ANONYMOUS' xmlns='urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:xmpp-sasl'>
c2s559bbc22b010                                       info      Authenticated as pzfe_wf6hul4nsz2@daily.signal.co
```
aioxmpp reports:
```
certificate verification failed (by OpenSSL)
Fatal error on tls handshake
protocol: <aioxmpp.protocol.XMLStream object at 0x0000022C311AC688>
transport: <aioopenssl.STARTTLSTransport object at 0x0000022C3118BDC8>
```

Let's say my problem is, how can I authenticated with Anonymous SASL as the second log snippet above with aioxmpp library.

items.title: Skip bookmarks e2e tests when they're not supported server-sided.
items.body:
Openfire does not support private-storage nor pep for anonymous sessions. The e2e tests use anonymous connections. As a result, `tests.bookmarks.test_e2e.TestBookmarks` throws an error when executed against Openfire.

`tests.bookmarks.test_e2e.TestBookmarks` should skip tests when bookmarks are not supported. As there's no documented way to detect support for bookmarks directly, this can be somewhat challenging. Maybe detect support for PEP or private-storage?

items.title: Have provisioner that uses username/password pairs
items.body: Please have a Provisioner that allows tests to be ran using non-anonymous accounts.

items.title: New feature: only run e2e tests
items.body: For usage in CI for servers, it would be interesting to have a way to (only) run the e2e tests (and not the unit tests).

```python
ConnectionError: stream shut down
Future exception was never retrieved
future: <Future finished exception=ConnectionError('stream shut down')>
ConnectionError: stream shut down

```

OpenSSL is clearly not able to verify my server certificate ('certificate verify failed') and I think the problem arises from the fact that aioxmpp is passing 127.0.0.1 as server common name to Openssl.

This obviously fails since my server common name is: mitlcsm.milano.ea.it.

The relevant portion of my code:
```python
    # set up the client object
    jid = aioxmpp.JID.fromstr("scmadministrator@127.0.0.1", strict=True)
    password = "somepsw"

    client = aioxmpp.PresenceManagedClient(
        jid,
        # aioxmpp.make_security_layer(password, no_verify=True,),
        aioxmpp.make_security_layer(password),
        override_peer=[
            ("mitlcsm.milano.ea.it", 5222, aioxmpp.connector.STARTTLSConnector())
        ],
    )
```
So I think aioxmpp is using my jid domain (127.0.0.1) instead of "mitlcsm.milano.ea.it" (specified in override_peer list) as a common name for cert validation.

Finally, I did check with plain openssl and the full certificate chain seems trusted:

```bash
openssl s_client -connect mitlcsm.milano.ea.it:5222 -starttls xmpp | grep verify
depth=2 DC = it, DC = ea, DC = milano, CN = milano-MIROOTCA01-CA
verify return:1
depth=1 DC = it, DC = ea, DC = milano, CN = EURA-CA
verify return:1
depth=0 C = IT, ST = Italia, L = Milano, O = EUROPASSISTANCE, OU = UCCE, CN = MITLCSM.milano.ea.it
verify return:1
```
Is there a way to overcome this issue? 

Thanks

items.title: XEP-0060: remote-server-not-found error

labels.name: question
labels.description: This is not a request, but a question about the project or a feature.

items.body:
Hi.

I'm trying to subscribe to an xmpp server.

My code:

```python
import aioxmpp
import asyncio

async def main():
    jid = aioxmpp.JID.fromstr("administrator@server_fqdn")
    sub_jid = aioxmpp.JID.fromstr("pubsub.127.0.0.1@server_fqdn")
    password = "password"

    client = aioxmpp.PresenceManagedClient(
        jid,
        aioxmpp.make_security_layer(
            password,
            no_verify=True,
        ),
    )

    # Creation of the publish subscribe connection pattern
    pubsubClient = client.summon(aioxmpp.PubSubClient)

    async with client.connected() as stream:

        # Subscribing on the node|topic the message containing the data required.
        result = await pubsubClient.subscribe(
            jid,
            node="ccp.campaign.updates.Campaign-002",
            subscription_jid=sub_jid,
        )

        print(result)

async def forever():
    while True:
        await main()

loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
loop.run_until_complete(forever())
```

When I run the script, I get back the following error:

> aioxmpp.errors.XMPPCancelError: {urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:xmpp-stanzas}remote-server-not-found

Now, I don't think this can be correct. With wireshark I can clearly see xmpp traffic exchanged between my workstation and the xmpp server. This means server_fqdn is correctly resolved.

Maybe I'm missing something obvious.

Is someone able to point me in the right direction?

Thanks

items.title: Echo bot example using message carbons

labels.name: example-request
labels.description: Request for an example which demonstrates a specific feature.

items.body: The current [echo bot example](https://github.com/horazont/aioxmpp/blob/devel/examples/echo_bot.py) does not use message carbons, and hence fails if the XMPP account is logged in elsewhere.

items.title: Service and toposort, again
items.body:
The toposort code is currently duplicated:

* `Client.summon` does a toposort on services on instanciation
* the `service.Meta` metaclass checks all services are toposortable and defines a total order on the services that is a valid toposort

While the latter feature makes debugging easier (by emitting an error at the definition of the class introducing the cycle), it has several problems:
* the run time is `O(N**2)` in the number of service classes `N`,  so it does not scale
* the total ordering information is only used for testing (and could be obtained there explicitly) and is otherwise useless and furthermore ill-defined (the topological sort is not unique). I think this feature should be removed.

The checking of the cycle-freeness can be substantially reduced, by only checking when the seldom used `ORDER_BEFORE` is used. Code using only `ORDER_AFTER` cannot introduce dependency loops (since the dependencies `ORDER_AFTER` has been declared before the current class even existed). So, it is sufficient to search through the dependency graph of the `ORDER_BEFORE` element to check for loops. This is only `O(n·m)` where `n` is the number of services actually in the dependency graph of that service and `m` is the average number of dependencies per service, instead of the total number of services!

labels.name: bug

items.body:
By mistake we have tried to subscribe to ourselves and PROSODY returns a PresenceType.ERROR message with an empty from field. This raises the following exception:

```
import asyncio

loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
```

username@serveripaddress is replaced by the account created in prosody.

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Outright bug: e.g. violation of specs, crashes, behaviour contrary to documentation, ….

items.title: Get rid of libxml dependency

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improve functionality: e.g. extend existing features, add new features, refactoring, …

labels.name: up-for-grabs
labels.description: Issue description is extensive enough that third parties can get started easily.

items.body:
We currently load libxml2 for a validation function. Ideally, we’d re-write this function in pure python to get rid of the burden to find libxml2 (despite it’ll be loaded anyways because we also depend on lxml).

**up-for-grabs note:** Please see the README and join our chat room if you want help or guidelines on how to implement this.

items.title: Loading xml2 lib does not work in MSYS2/Windows

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Outright bug: e.g. violation of specs, crashes, behaviour contrary to documentation, ….

items.body:
if libxml2 is installed on Windows via MSYS2 the .dll is called `libxml2-2.dll`

So the code would have to be adapted

xml.py
```python
if os.name == 'nt':
    libxml2 = ctypes.cdll.LoadLibrary(
        ctypes.util.find_library("libxml2-2.dll"),
    )
```

i think over time you will have to test for multiple names, depending on where and how lxml is installed

items.title: RFC 6120: Enum-ify error conditions

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improve functionality: e.g. extend existing features, add new features, refactoring, …

items.body:
Having to compose the error conditions with ``(namespaces.stanzas, "something")`` is cumbersome and error-prone.

I’d like to convert them to an Enum through the whole stack. Since no new conditions can be added to the RFC this should be fine (it provides a separate way to extend the set of representable errors).

items.title: Ensure that stream management is enabled synchronously

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Outright bug: e.g. violation of specs, crashes, behaviour contrary to documentation, ….

items.body:
Apparently, it is currently possible to make aioxmpp fail by sending a ``<{sm}r/>`` right after enabling stream management. Of course, this is nonsensical to do normally, but in combination with #173, it is possible that we’re sending stanzas right after the ``<{sm}enable/>``, prompting the peer to reply with ``<{sm}enabled/>``, some replies and then ``<{sm}r/>``. 

In this case, it is apparently possible (I’ve got logs to prove it!) that the SM handlers are not attached to the XML stream yet, thus making the stream fail with ``unsupported-stanza-type``.

items.title: Do not allow forwarding of application stanzas until resource binding has completed

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Outright bug: e.g. violation of specs, crashes, behaviour contrary to documentation, ….

items.body:
Currently, when an application enqueues a stanza before the stream has first been established, the stanza is sent *before* the resource binding takes place. This can lead to all sorts of funny issues:

* messages will be lost or errored back
* IQ requests will fail with not-authorized
* presence may be errored back or be lost

… much of this (except IQs) happens without the application being the wiser.

The stream should not accept stanzas from services or application code until it has been fully negotiated.

labels.name: bug

items.body:
@sebastianriese correctly pointed out that XEP-0092 REQUIRES that ``<name/>`` and ``<version/>`` are included in a result.

We have three options:

* Force ``<name/>`` and ``<version/>`` to be the defaults (``"aioxmpp"``/``aioxmpp.__version__``) instead of None when deleted.
* Do not answer queries if either is set to None (reply with ``<service-unavailable/>``)
* Set them to ``"unspecified"``, ``"unspecified"`` instead.

Opinions?

items.title: Replace use of asyncio.async with asyncio.ensure_future and provide fallback

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improve functionality: e.g. extend existing features, add new features, refactoring, …

labels.name: up-for-grabs
labels.description: Issue description is extensive enough that third parties can get started easily.

items.body:
This is part of #11.

The workflow would be like this:

1. Put

    ```python
    if not hasattr(asyncio, "ensure_future"):
        asyncio.ensure_future = getattr(asyncio, "async")
    ```

    early in ``aioxmpp/__init__.py``.

2. Replace all uses of asyncio.async with asyncio.ensure_future.
3. Ensure that you catch unittest.mock.patch invocations in step 2.
4. Make sure the tests pass.
5. Enjoy!

**up-for-grabs note:** Please see the README and join our chat room if you want help or guidelines on how to implement this.

items.title: XEP-0045: Handle messages sent to the MUC during join
items.body:
Found by @ge0rg via jabbercat/jabbercat#21.

Messages sent with a MUC Room which has not completed the join yet are handled in a weird manner and we need to figure out how to do this right.

Protocol-wise, sending the message should be fine at that time. However, the occupant object for the local occupant isn’t set up properly yet, which leads to a problematic ``on_message`` event.

Possible solutions:

* delay the ``on_message`` event until the history replay has completed. This means that we need a queue for pending ``on_message`` events in MUC and we also need to time this carefully w.r.t. message tracking. Plus handling of join errors (the message should be bounced internally in that case).
* reject attempts to send a message before join has completed.

We only need an "okay" solution in aioxmpp. I think I could live with rejecting send attempts before the join has completed; clients should handle this properly anyways.

Thoughts?

items.title: cccccchdlcgnjuiglfejuijbujlfiubrijtrltlenfrr
Provide IQ API with strong ordering guarantees

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improve functionality: e.g. extend existing features, add new features, refactoring, …

items.body:
The current IQ API has a main shortcoming: due to its inherent focus on coroutines, the strong ordering guarantees of the XMPP XML Stream get lost a bit. For example, when registering IQ handlers for two different IQs, we cannot say for sure which IQ handler executes first when the two IQs arrive in the same chunk of buffer handed to the XMLStream protocol. Another example are possible races between the return of the ``send`` coroutine function and execution of IQ request handlers.

This has caused quite a bit of headache in the roster and avatar implementations, since they act on rather large state and that state needs to stay in sync with the servers state to be valid.

To solve this, I propose the following API changes:

1. ``register_iq_request_coro`` -> ``register_iq_request_awaitable`` and allow any function which returns an awaitable to be registered. This includes coroutine functions, but also normal functions returning a Future. The result of the future must adhere to the current specifications for IQ request coroutine function results.

    The ``_coro`` version would become an alias to the ``_awaitable`` version, and is deprecated. To be removed in 1.0.

2. ``send`` gets an additional "callback" argument for use with IQ get/set stanzas. Now I’m not 100% sure. Either:

    1. the callback must be a function returning an awaitable. It is executed right when the IQ result is received. The awaitable is awaited by and the result is returned from ``send``. **or**

    2. the callback must be a normal function without specific return type. It is simply executed right when the IQ result is received. It does not influence the result of ``send``.

  In any case, if the callback is omitted, ``send`` behaves as currently. If the ``callback`` is passed for non-IQ-request stanzas, an error is raised.

This way, we will have a strong order guarantee, since those functions will be called right from the stanza processing loop.

Benefits: we should get around quite a bit of locking, e.g. the global avatar lock (#141) and the roster lock, if we play it well.

items.title: XEP-0084: Try to remove the Global Avatar Lock

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improve functionality: e.g. extend existing features, add new features, refactoring, …

items.body:
The current avatar implementation uses a lock over the data structures, preventing more than one simultaneous query for avatar metadata.

This is bad, because when the s2s to a peers server fails, we may block the whole avatar subsystem for quite some time (in the order of 10 seconds).

If possible, we should find a way to remove the Global Avatar Lock.

items.title: XEP-0084: HTTP support

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improve functionality: e.g. extend existing features, add new features, refactoring, …

labels.name: up-for-grabs
labels.description: Issue description is extensive enough that third parties can get started easily.

items.body:
Avatars can also be stored on some HTTP server. This is especially relevant given that XMPP servers will usually not allow clients to send large stanzas or store large blobs in PEP. This means that often, clients either do not upload ``image/png`` avatars at all (violating XEP-0084) or upload only a heavily downscaled avatar to PEP.

To implement this, an **optional** dependency on [aiohttp](https://github.com/aio-libs/aiohttp) should be added.

**up-for-grabs notes:** Please see the README and join our chat room if you want help or guidelines on how to implement this.

items.title: XEP-0300: Announce supported hash functions via DiscoServer

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improve functionality: e.g. extend existing features, add new features, refactoring, …

labels.name: up-for-grabs
labels.description: Issue description is extensive enough that third parties can get started easily.

items.body:
[XEP-0300 specifies](https://xmpp.org/extensions/xep-0300.html#disco) that the set of supported hash functions can be announced via [XEP-0030 Service Discovery](https://xmpp.org/extensions/xep-0030.html).

To make aioxmpp easily announce those, the aioxmpp.hashes module could use a re-factor to also provide a HashesService.

This service would do two things:

1. depend on DiscoServer and announce the features for the locally supported hash functions (excluding those marked as MUST NOT in XEP-0300)
2. depend on DiscoClient and provide a coroutine which obtains the intersection of the locally supported hash functions and the remotely supported hash functions.

**up-for-grabs note:** Please see the README and join our chat room if you want help or guidelines on how to implement this.

items.title: Refactor ping handling out of StanzaStream

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improve functionality: e.g. extend existing features, add new features, refactoring, …

items.body:
This should help with a proper implementation of #96.

The idea is to refactor the whole ping handling out of the StanzaStream into separate classes (for XMPP Ping, SM Ping and possibly other implementations). StanzaStream must then provide the appropriate callbacks, including for reception and sending of ``<r/>`` and ``<a/>`` elements (while still handling SM itself).

labels.name: enhancement

items.body:
Biboumi uses this to display mode changes, there are other use cases for this as well. I think we don’t handle those in a meaningful way yet.

In general, the meaning is "this is a message from the service, not from a participant, referring to this muc specifically".

Reportedly, some services use this for captchas too (with type="normal" instead of type="groupchat"…).

items.title: [XEP-0048/bookmarks] Provide more convenient API

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improve functionality: e.g. extend existing features, add new features, refactoring, …

items.body:
I imagine the following interface:

```python
# emitted when a bookmark is added, either by remote or local party
on_bookmark_added = Signal()
# emitted when a bookmark is removed, either by remote or local party
on_bookmark_removed = Signal()
# emitted when a bookmark is changed, either by remote or local party
on_bookmark_changed = Signal()

async def add_bookmark(self, bookmark_xso):
    """
    Add or update a bookmark to server-side storage.
    """

async def update_bookmark(self, old, new):
    """
    Replace a bookmark.

    This operation fails if no bookmark equal to ``old`` is found. 
    Otherwise, ``old`` is replaced by ``new``. ``old`` must be equal 
    to ``new``.
    """

async def remove_bookmark(self, bookmark_xso):
    """
    Remove a bookmark from server-side storage.
    """

async def get_bookmarks(self):
    """
    Return all bookmarks from server-side storage.
    """

async def sync(self):
    """
    Force fetch of bookmarks from the server, unless PubSub is used. Emits events.
    """
```

Notes:
* the events shall not fire spuriously when multiple writes are required due to race conditions
* if pubsub storage is used, ``sync`` should be a no-op
* if private XML storage is used, ``sync`` must be called periodically to be able to emit the events
* add, remove and get also cause events to be emitted, since all will require reads of the remote storage
* equivalence of bookmarks depends on the type:

   * for ``<conference/>``: use bare jid for equality
   * for ``<url/>``: use url for equality

* equivalent bookmarks are not duplicated on ``add``, only updated
* equivalence is used to determine which bookmark to remove
* the user should not have to take care of performing multiple writes if a race condition with another entity occurs.
* a ``sync`` shall happen implicitly when the stream is established

items.title: Get rid of orderedset dependency
items.body:
Since orderedset is hard to get on current distributions and is thus making packaging difficult, we should see if we can replace it with something more widespread.

A good candidate is [sortedcollections](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/sortedcollections), which is packaged in Debian and which offers a OrderedSet which may be a drop-in replacement to orderedset.

items.title: Add method to disable XEP-0198

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improve functionality: e.g. extend existing features, add new features, refactoring, …

items.body:
In some cases it's preferable to disable stream management.

My current use case is that I have a device that use aioxmpp for communication. It's supposed to have a quite stable network connection. But when the network goes down, for any reason, I would prefer to be notified immediately of the problem. I'm not an expert at XEP-0198, but I think it's because of the stream management that the connection is displayed as alive for a long while after the network goes down.

I've been informed that there is currently no way to disable XEP 0198.
